title: Is "gay" an offensive and therefore bannable word?

replies.body: When used in negative context (as an insult for example) it's derogatory towards people who are gay.

It's something people don't really want to think about, but society in the 2000s was not a nice place for people who were homosexual. Using "gay" as a negative meaning word back then, whether or not the person thought about what they were saying, was a sign of how deeply ingrained it was in society that being gay was something to be ashamed of.

To the point where a term that refers to homosexuals was used as a common insult or expletive.

>Using "gay" as a negative meaning word back then [...] was a sign of how deeply ingrained it was in society that being gay was something to be ashamed of.

Couldn't agree more.

There's a reason why there's a whole bunch of insults based on homosexuality, that even tend to be directly translatable into other languages, with both the same severity of the insult and the same meaning in regards to homosexuality.

Being in denial about that reason may be relatable to some extent, but it's just that: Denial.

I still cringe at how I'd use those terms in front of one of my best friends, who is gay. If I had known at the time, I probably would have realized much sooner just how insensitive that was.

you can't let them just claim it without a fight.  it used to mean joyful/carefree 

around the 1960's+ it became accepted to commonly mean homosexual

but in the 2000's it was commonly used as "stupid/rubbish" by young people.

we have the right to the word gay too. especially since we are GAYmers or gamers  it's in our name.

words change, it's not insensitive to use gay as stupid.   like saying it would be insensitive to say "walk a straight path" just because the word straight was also adapted/changed to mean the opposite of homosexual, where as before it was strictly used as "behave/other things straight used to mean"

Two massive differences:
A) Talking about a straight path is a neutral description. It's neither positive nor negative.
B) Talking about a straight path is in no way a reference to heterosexuals.

Small sidenote here is that it's actually the other way around: Heterosexuals being called "straight" is actually yet another sign of… well… not necessarily intolerance towards homosexuality, but definitely a sign of heteronormativity.

Anyway, the point is exactly **why** it was used in the 2000's as a synonym for stupid/lame/etc. It's not about the strict meaning of the word, but the way this meaning came about. It's about how this became a cultural meme.
And the simple and straight forward answer to that is simply that homosexuality at that time was itself still widely regarded as something inherently negative.

As for "we have the right to the word, too" and "you can't let them claim it without a fight": There's nothing wrong with reclaiming a word… but the whole idea of reclaiming words is to void them of their negative connotation.

Using gay to neutrally refer to homosexuals does that. Likewise it's reclaiming when homosexuals call each other "f%%%%ts" and the likes. For what it's worth, if you want to use it in its original meaning to refer to something joyful I would also regard that as a way to reclaim the word.

What absolutely **doesn't** reclaim the word is deliberately continuing to use the words with a negative connotation. If you retain its negative meaning, then you are also retaining the cultural meme that created it: The idea that homosexuality is bad.

That's why it's insensitive to use those words this way.
To be clear: Not homophobic. Just insensitive.

Automated system doesn't know context tho. To it, in sentences "I like that new Rainbow Poro icon symbolizing gay pride month" and "you fucking gay piece of shit* word "gay" has the same meaning. Unlike the F-word which is 100% inappropriate no matter where it's used, the word "gay" is ambiguous and highly dependent on context, so it should be a gray zone.

But why would you even bring it up during a game?  It adds nothing and only distracts.  No one cares about identity stuff. They care about whether you're helping them win.

If you want to talk about identity politics, keep it to private comms or better yet, outside the game.

Although I do not speak for Riot, in general terms describing something as "gay" when that thing being discussed is actually gay ex: The rainbow flag is gay/symbolizes gayness is not offensive because it is just a statement of fact. On the other hand using "Gay" as an insult ex: you're gay, that's so gay, etc. is offensive because it slanders the meaning of gay and those who identify as gay.

Now what will it take for Riot to ban you? For you to say the word, someone to get offended and report you, and Riot to agree you used the term slanderously.
